mn81:1.1.comm: This lively story is one of the most developed of the early canonical Jātakas. The popularity of the story is attested by the many parallels, which include a retelling of the story by the deity who had been Ghaṭīkāra (SN 1.50). Ghaṭīkāra’s virtues as an ideal lay follower are extolled; his kindness, faith, and contentment, and especially his practice of economic harmlessness through rejection of the contractual market economy.

mn81:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu cārikaṃ carati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ.
mn81:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn81:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā maggā okkamma aññatarasmiṃ padese sitaṃ pātvākāsi.
mn81:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha left the road, and at a certain spot he smiled.

mn81:2.3.pli: “ko nu kho hetu, ko paccayo bhagavato sitassa pātukammāya?
mn81:2.3.eng: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?

mn81:2.4.eng: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”

mn81:2.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando ekaṃsaṃ cīvaraṃ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:2.5.eng: So Ānanda arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

mn81:2.6.pli: “ko nu kho, bhante, hetu, ko paccayo bhagavato sitassa pātukammāya?
mn81:2.6.eng: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?

mn81:2.7.eng: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”

mn81:3.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, imasmiṃ padese vegaḷiṅgaṃ nāma gāmanigamo ahosi iddho ceva phīto ca bahujano ākiṇṇamanusso.
mn81:3.1.eng: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, there was a market town in this spot named Vebhaliṅga. It was successful and prosperous, populous, full of humans.
mn81:3.1.comm: Each of the occasions when the Buddha smiled in this way served as an introduction to an uplifting story of the past. In MN 83, the Buddha tells of the fabled king Maghadeva of Mithilā, who went forth and practice the divine meditations. AN 5.180, like the current sutta, tells the story of a virtuous layperson in the time of Kassapa Buddha. Both the Kassapa stories are set in Kosala. | Vebhaliṅga is known only from this context and there are many variant readings. | Here the compound gāmanigama, elsewhere “village or town” clearly means “market town”. The same idiom is found in Sanskrit versions of this text (vaibhiḍiṅgī nāma grāmanigamo, Mūlasarvāstivāda Vinaya 17.390).

mn81:3.2.pli: Vegaḷiṅgaṃ kho, ānanda, gāmanigamaṃ kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho upanissāya vihāsi.
mn81:3.2.eng: And Kassapa, a blessed one, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, lived supported by Vebhaliṅga.

mn81:3.3.pli: Idha sudaṃ, ānanda, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ārāmo ahosi.
mn81:3.3.eng: It was here, in fact, that he had his monastery,

mn81:3.4.pli: Idha sudaṃ, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho nisinnako bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ovadatī”ti.
mn81:3.4.eng: where he advised the mendicant Saṅgha while seated.”

mn81:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:4.1.eng: Then Ānanda spread out his outer robe folded in four and said to the Buddha,

mn81:4.2.eng: “Well then, sir, may the Blessed One sit here!

mn81:4.3.pli: Ayaṃ bhūmipadeso dvīhi arahantehi sammāsambuddhehi paribhutto bhavissatī”ti.
mn81:4.3.eng: Then this piece of land will have been occupied by two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas.”

mn81:4.4.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.

mn81:4.5.pli: Nisajja kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ āmantesi:
mn81:4.5.eng: When he was seated he said to Venerable Ānanda:

mn81:5.1.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, ānanda, imasmiṃ padese vegaḷiṅgaṃ nāma gāmanigamo ahosi iddho ceva phīto ca bahujano ākiṇṇamanusso.
mn81:5.1.eng: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, there was a market town in this spot named Vebhaliṅga. It was successful and prosperous, populous, full of humans.

mn81:5.2.pli: Vegaḷiṅgaṃ kho, ānanda, gāmanigamaṃ kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho upanissāya vihāsi.
mn81:5.2.eng: And Kassapa, a blessed one, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, lived supported by Vebhaliṅga.

mn81:5.3.pli: Idha sudaṃ, ānanda, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa ārāmo ahosi.
mn81:5.3.eng: It was here, in fact, that he had his monastery,

mn81:5.4.pli: Idha sudaṃ, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho nisinnako bhikkhusaṅghaṃ ovadati.
mn81:5.4.eng: where he advised the mendicant Saṅgha while seated.

mn81:6.1.pli: Vegaḷiṅge kho, ānanda, gāmanigame ghaṭikāro nāma kumbhakāro kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa upaṭṭhāko ahosi aggupaṭṭhāko.
mn81:6.1.eng: The Buddha Kassapa had as chief supporter in Vebhaliṅga a potter named Ghaṭīkāra.

mn81:6.2.pli: Ghaṭikārassa kho, ānanda, kumbhakārassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo sahāyo ahosi piyasahāyo.
mn81:6.2.eng: Ghaṭīkāra had a dear friend named Jotipāla, a student.
mn81:6.2.comm: Various texts of the northern Sarvāstivāda movement, including the Madhyama-āgama and the Saṅghabhedavastu, speak instead of the potter Nandīpāla and the Brahmin youth Uttara. | Ghaṭīkāra (“potter”) Nandīpāla is also referred to by his clan name Bhaggava. | Jotipāla means “guardian of the sacred flame”, i.e. someone who maintains the Vedic fire ritual, as attested by another Jotipāla of the past (DN 19:47.26). Yet another Jotipāla was a religious founder of the past (AN 6.54:18.1, AN 7.73:2.5). The name seems to appear only in Buddhist sources. Given that it is always in legendary contexts, it is probably a vocational epithet like Ghaṭīkāra.

mn81:6.3.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi:

mn81:6.4.pli: ‘āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:6.4.eng: ‘Come, dear Jotipāla, let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
mn81:6.4.comm: Kassapa (Sanskrit Kaśyapa) means “tortoise”. It is a common Brahmanical clan name, stemming from an ancient figure reckoned as the eldest of the “seven sages”, to whom some Vedic verses are attributed. Further details of the Buddha Kassapa’s time are found at DN 14:1.4.6, SN 15.20:4.1, and SN 48.57:3.1.

mn81:6.5.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:6.5.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
mn81:6.5.comm: Sādhusammata is normally an epithet of (real or supposed) saints. Here it is the “sight” (dassana) of the saint that is deemed holy. This is an early example of the belief known in Hinduism as darshana, that the sight of a holy person, place, or object was auspicious and conveyed blessings on the seer. This topic is also treated at Snp 4.4 and AN 6.30.

mn81:6.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn81:6.6.eng: When he said this, Jotipāla said to him,

mn81:6.8.pli: Kiṃ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti?
mn81:6.8.eng: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’

mn81:6.10.pli: tatiyampi kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:6.10.eng: and a third time, Ghaṭīkāra addressed Jotipāla,

mn81:6.11.pli: ‘āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:6.11.eng: ‘Come, dear Jotipāla, let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn81:6.12.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:6.12.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:6.13.pli: Tatiyampi kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn81:6.13.eng: For a third time, Jotipāla said to him,

mn81:6.15.pli: Kiṃ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti?
mn81:6.15.eng: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’

mn81:6.16.pli: ‘Tena hi, samma jotipāla, sottisināniṃ ādāya nadiṃ gamissāma sināyitun’ti.
mn81:6.16.eng: ‘Well then, dear Jotipāla, let’s take some bathing cleanser and go to the river to bathe.’
mn81:6.16.comm: Sotti is uncertain. I take it as from the root suc in the sense “cleanser”. However, it may be related to Sanskrit śukti (from the same root), which is mentioned by Varāhamihira as an ingredient in perfumed bath powders fit for a king (Bṛhat Saṁhitā 77). There, it is probably either powdered or ashen oyster shell, which is included as an exfoliant in some modern soaps, or else perfume from a plant whose leaves or flowers resemble oysters. The commentary, identifying it with the kuruvindakasutti that was banned for mendicants at Kd 15:1.3.18, evidently derives it from sutta (“string”) and explains it as a string of resin-balls compounded with kuruvindaka (itself uncertain, possibly a herb). However, these explanations all seem dubious, as Pali texts treat sotti as a normal means of washing, and should not require specialized ingredients or methods (AN 3.70:8.2, MN 93:10.5).

mn81:6.17.pli: ‘Evaṃ, sammā’ti kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa paccassosi.

mn81:6.18.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo sottisināniṃ ādāya nadiṃ agamaṃsu sināyituṃ.

mn81:7.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi:

mn81:7.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ, samma jotipāla, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa avidūre ārāmo.
mn81:7.2.eng: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.

mn81:7.3.pli: Āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:7.3.eng: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn81:7.4.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:7.4.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:7.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn81:7.5.eng: When he said this, Jotipāla said to him,

mn81:7.7.pli: Kiṃ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti?
mn81:7.7.eng: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’

mn81:7.9.pli: tatiyampi kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:7.9.eng: and a third time, Ghaṭīkāra addressed Jotipāla,

mn81:7.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ, samma jotipāla, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa avidūre ārāmo.
mn81:7.10.eng: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.

mn81:7.11.pli: Āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:7.11.eng: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn81:7.12.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:7.12.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:7.13.pli: Tatiyampi kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn81:7.13.eng: For a third time, Jotipāla said to him,

mn81:7.15.pli: Kiṃ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti?
mn81:7.15.eng: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’

mn81:8.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ ovaṭṭikāyaṃ parāmasitvā etadavoca:
mn81:8.1.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra grabbed Jotipāla by the skirt-hem and said,
mn81:8.1.comm: The ovaṭṭikā is the turned-over hem of a skirt or sarong that holds it up (see Bu NP 10:1.2.7).

mn81:8.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ, samma jotipāla, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa avidūre ārāmo.
mn81:8.2.eng: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.

mn81:8.3.pli: Āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:8.3.eng: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn81:8.4.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:8.4.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:8.5.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ovaṭṭikaṃ vinivaṭṭetvā ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:
mn81:8.5.eng: So Jotipāla undid his skirt-hem and said to Ghaṭīkāra,
mn81:8.5.comm: Leaving him, apparently, naked standing in the water.

mn81:8.7.pli: Kiṃ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti?
mn81:8.7.eng: What’s the use of seeing that shaveling, that fake ascetic?’

mn81:9.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro jotipālaṃ māṇavaṃ sīsaṃnhātaṃ kesesu parāmasitvā etadavoca:
mn81:9.1.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra grabbed Jotipāla by the hair of his freshly-washed head and said,
mn81:9.1.comm: Manusmṛti 4.83 forbids grabbing hair (keśagraha), which was an act of dominance in wrestling. It is forbidden in anger, notes Medhātithi’s commentary, but permitted in sex. Mahābhārata 5.91.11a beautifully explains how such rules are meant to be understood in context: “The learned regard him to be a wretch who does not by his solicitation seek to save a friend who is about to sink in calamity. Striving to the best of his might, even to the extent of seizing him by the hair, one should seek to dissuade a friend from an improper act. In that case, he that acts so, instead of incurring blame, reaps praise” (Kisari Mohan Ganguli’s translation, Section 93, Bhagavat-yāna Parva).

mn81:9.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ, samma jotipāla, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa avidūre ārāmo.
mn81:9.2.eng: ‘Dear Jotipāla, the Buddha Kassapa’s monastery is not far away.

mn81:9.3.pli: Āyāma, samma jotipāla, kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāma.
mn81:9.3.eng: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.

mn81:9.4.pli: Sādhusammatañhi me tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:9.4.eng: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:9.5.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, jotipālassa māṇavassa etadahosi:

mn81:9.7.pli: Yatra hi nāmāyaṃ ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro ittarajacco samāno amhākaṃ sīsaṃnhātānaṃ kesesu parāmasitabbaṃ maññissati;
mn81:9.7.eng: how this potter Ghaṭīkāra, though of lowly birth, should presume to grab me by the hair of my freshly-washed head!
mn81:9.7.comm: Pottery is said to be a low craft at Bu Pc 2:2.1.30.

mn81:9.8.pli: na vatidaṃ kira orakaṃ maññe bhavissatī’ti;
mn81:9.8.eng: This must be no ordinary matter.’

mn81:9.10.eng: ‘You’d even milk it to this extent, dear Ghaṭīkāra?’
mn81:9.10.comm: Dohī is “milking”, as in anavasesadohī “milk dry”, an idiom which is used in the sense of “pushing things too far” (MN 33:13.1, AN 11.17:12.1).

mn81:9.11.eng: ‘I even milk it to this extent, dear Jotipāla.

mn81:9.12.pli: Tathā hi pana me sādhusammataṃ tassa bhagavato dassanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassā’ti.
mn81:9.12.eng: For that is how holy I deem it to see that Blessed One.’

mn81:9.13.eng: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, release me, we shall go.’

mn81:10.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo yena kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Jotipālo pana māṇavo kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn81:10.1.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra the potter and Jotipāla the student went to the Buddha Kassapa. Ghaṭīkāra bowed and sat down to one side, but Jotipāla exchanged greetings with the Buddha and sat down to one side.

mn81:10.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:10.2.eng: Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,

mn81:10.3.pli: ‘ayaṃ me, bhante, jotipālo māṇavo sahāyo piyasahāyo.
mn81:10.3.eng: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.

mn81:10.5.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho ghaṭikārañca kumbhakāraṃ jotipālañca māṇavaṃ dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
mn81:10.5.eng: Then the Buddha Kassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla with a Dhamma talk.

mn81:10.6.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
mn81:10.6.eng: Then they got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha Kassapa, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

mn81:11.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ etadavoca:

mn81:11.2.pli: ‘imaṃ nu tvaṃ, samma ghaṭikāra, dhammaṃ suṇanto atha ca pana agārasmā anagāriyaṃ na pabbajissasī’ti?
mn81:11.2.eng: ‘Dear Ghaṭīkāra, you have heard this teaching, so why don’t you go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn81:11.3.pli: ‘Nanu maṃ, samma jotipāla, jānāsi, andhe jiṇṇe mātāpitaro posemī’ti?
mn81:11.3.eng: ‘Don’t you know, dear Jotipāla, that I  provide for my blind old parents?’

mn81:11.4.pli: ‘Tena hi, samma ghaṭikāra, ahaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajissāmī’ti.
mn81:11.4.eng: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’

mn81:12.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro ca kumbhakāro jotipālo ca māṇavo yena kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, ānanda, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:12.1.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla went to the Buddha Kassapa, bowed and sat down to one side. Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,

mn81:12.2.pli: ‘ayaṃ me, bhante, jotipālo māṇavo sahāyo piyasahāyo.
mn81:12.2.eng: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.

mn81:12.3.eng: Please give him the going forth.’

mn81:12.4.pli: Alattha kho, ānanda, jotipālo māṇavo kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
mn81:12.4.eng: And Jotipāla the student received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

mn81:13.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho acirūpasampanne jotipāle māṇave aḍḍhamāsupasampanne vegaḷiṅge yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena bārāṇasī tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn81:13.1.eng: Not long after Jotipāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha Kassapa—having stayed in Vebhaliṅga as long as he pleased—set out for Varanasi.
mn81:13.1.comm: Varanasi, one of the oldest cities in the world, was the capital of the Kāsī kingdom. It lost its status as an independent kingdom shortly before the Buddha, when it was taken over by Kosala. It appears in countless Buddhist stories of the past as the dominant city of the region in what appears to be a timeless and ageless past. However, despite its great antiquity, it is a historical settlement, of which the discovered remains date back to perhaps 1200 BCE; it was a capital city from perhaps 800 BCE. It would have enjoyed its status as a major city for a period of a few hundred years before the Buddha, during which time all these stories were set.

mn81:13.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena bārāṇasī tadavasari.
mn81:13.2.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Varanasi,

mn81:13.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye.
mn81:13.3.eng: where he stayed near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.

mn81:14.1.pli: Assosi kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā: ‘kassapo kira bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho bārāṇasiṃ anuppatto bārāṇasiyaṃ viharati isipatane migadāye’ti.
mn81:14.1.eng: King Kikī of Kāsi heard that he had arrived.
mn81:14.1.comm: Kikī (“blue jay”) is also the king in the time of Kassapa at DN 14:1.12.20. No king of this name appears to be attested in Puranic lineages. By the time of the Buddha, the much-conquered city of Varanasi was subject to first Kosala and then Magadha. This sutta establishes, however, that the true ancient king of the city was in fact a disciple of the past Buddha. | The suttas of this chapter all deal with kings in one way or another. Leaving aside the final five, all of which which Pasenadi of Kosala, we encounter royalty of of Kuru, Kāsī, Videha, Sūrasena, Bhaggā, and indirectly of Avanti and Kosambī. Thus the chapter serves to show that not just the well-known cases of Pasenadi and Bimbisāra, as well as the republican nations such as Vajjī and Sakya, were devoted to the Buddha, but the overwhelming majority of the kings of the time. Many, perhaps all, of these kings belong to what the Puranas later called the “lunar” dynasty, in contrast with the Buddha’s “solar” lineage.

mn81:14.2.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhadraṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi bārāṇasiyā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ dassanāya.
mn81:14.2.eng: He had the finest carriages harnessed. He then mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Varanasi to see the Buddha Kassapa.

mn81:14.3.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova yena kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn81:14.3.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha Kassapa on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side.

mn81:14.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho, ānanda, kikiṃ kāsirājānaṃ kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
mn81:14.4.eng: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.

mn81:14.5.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dhammiyā kathāya sandassito samādapito samuttejito sampahaṃsito kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:14.5.eng: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha,

mn81:14.6.pli: ‘adhivāsetu me, bhante, bhagavā svātanāya bhattaṃ saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghenā’ti.
mn81:14.6.eng: ‘Sir, would the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?’

mn81:14.7.pli: Adhivāsesi kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho tuṇhībhāvena.
mn81:14.7.eng: The Buddha Kassapa consented with silence.

mn81:15.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapassa bhagavato sammāsambuddhassa adhivāsanaṃ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
mn81:15.1.eng: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, King Kikī got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

mn81:16.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino vigatakāḷakaṃ anekasūpaṃ anekabyañjanaṃ, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kālaṃ ārocāpesi:
mn81:16.1.eng: And when the night had passed, King Kikī had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home—soft saffron rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
mn81:16.1.comm: For “soft saffron rice” prefer the reading paṇḍumudikassa.

mn81:16.2.eng: ‘Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.’

mn81:17.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kikissa kāsirañño nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi saddhiṃ bhikkhusaṅghena.
mn81:17.1.eng: Then Kassapa Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of King Kikī, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn81:17.2.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā buddhappamukhaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mn81:17.2.eng: Then King Kikī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

mn81:17.3.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ bhuttāviṃ onītapattapāṇiṃ aññataraṃ nīcaṃ āsanaṃ gahetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
mn81:17.3.eng: When the Buddha Kassapa had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, King Kikī took a low seat and sat to one side.

mn81:17.4.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:17.4.eng: There he said to the Buddha Kassapa,

mn81:17.5.eng: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.

mn81:17.6.eng: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’
mn81:17.6.comm: The king is promising that the offerings for the whole Sangha will be as luxurious as the ones just offered.

mn81:17.8.eng: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’

mn81:17.10.pli: tatiyampi kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:17.10.eng: and a third time King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,

mn81:17.11.eng: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.

mn81:17.12.eng: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’

mn81:17.14.eng: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’

mn81:17.15.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikissa kāsirañño ‘na me kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho adhivāseti bārāṇasiyaṃ vassāvāsan’ti ahudeva aññathattaṃ, ahu domanassaṃ.
mn81:17.15.eng: Then King Kikī, thinking, ‘The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,’ became sad and upset.

mn81:17.16.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā kassapaṃ bhagavantaṃ arahantaṃ sammāsambuddhaṃ etadavoca:
mn81:17.16.eng: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,

mn81:17.17.pli: ‘atthi nu kho, bhante, añño koci mayā upaṭṭhākataro’ti?
mn81:17.17.eng: ‘Sir, do you have another supporter better than me?’
mn81:17.17.comm: The Buddha does not take the bait of describing someone  as “better”; rather, he describes Ghaṭīkāra’s qualities.

mn81:18.1.eng: ‘Great king, there is a market town named Vebhaliṅga,

mn81:18.2.eng: where there is a potter named Ghaṭīkāra.

mn81:18.4.pli: Tuyhaṃ kho pana, mahārāja, na me kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho adhivāseti bārāṇasiyaṃ vassāvāsanti attheva aññathattaṃ, atthi domanassaṃ.
mn81:18.4.eng: Now, great king, when you thought, “The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,” you became sad and upset.

mn81:18.5.pli: Tayidaṃ ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa natthi ca na ca bhavissati.
mn81:18.5.eng: But Ghaṭīkāra doesn’t get upset, nor will he.

mn81:18.6.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato.
mn81:18.6.eng: Ghaṭīkāra has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

mn81:18.7.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pāṇātipātā paṭivirato, adinnādānā paṭivirato, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato, musāvādā paṭivirato, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato.
mn81:18.7.eng: He doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

mn81:18.8.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro buddhe aveccappasādena samannāgato, dhamme aveccappasādena samannāgato, saṅghe aveccappasādena samannāgato, ariyakantehi sīlehi samannāgato.
mn81:18.8.eng: He has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and possesses the ethics loved by the noble ones.

mn81:18.9.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro dukkhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhasamudaye nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhe nikkaṅkho, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya nikkaṅkho.
mn81:18.9.eng: He is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
mn81:18.9.comm: This shows him to be one of the noble ones.

mn81:18.10.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro ekabhattiko brahmacārī sīlavā kalyāṇadhammo.
mn81:18.10.eng: He eats in one part of the day; he’s chaste, ethical, and of good character.
mn81:18.10.comm: This is equivalent to the eight precepts.

mn81:18.11.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro nikkhittamaṇisuvaṇṇo apetajātarūparajato.
mn81:18.11.eng: He has set aside gems and gold, and quit using gold and currency.
mn81:18.11.comm: The same is said of Buddhist mendicants at SN 42.10:2.4. This parallels the ten precepts of the sāmaṇera, which forbid using money (Kd 1:56.1.14).

mn81:18.12.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pannamusalo na sahatthā pathaviṃ khaṇati.
mn81:18.12.eng: He has put down the shovel and doesn’t dig the earth with his own hands.
mn81:18.12.comm: Also said of ancient Brahmanical hermits at DN 27:22.6. Digging the earth is an offence for mendicants (Bu Pc 10).

mn81:18.13.pli: Yaṃ hoti kūlapaluggaṃ vā mūsikukkaro vā taṃ kājena āharitvā bhājanaṃ karitvā evamāha:
mn81:18.13.eng: He takes what has crumbled off by a riverbank or been dug up by mice, and brings it back in a carrier. When he has made a pot, he says,

mn81:18.14.pli: “ettha yo icchati taṇḍulapaṭibhastāni vā muggapaṭibhastāni vā kaḷāyapaṭibhastāni vā nikkhipitvā yaṃ icchati taṃ haratū”ti.
mn81:18.14.eng: “Anyone may leave bagged sesame, mung beans, or chickpeas here and take what they wish.”
mn81:18.14.comm: He made a living by purely voluntary exchange rather than contractual obligations.

mn81:18.15.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro andhe jiṇṇe mātāpitaro poseti.
mn81:18.15.eng: He provided for his blind old parents.

mn81:18.16.pli: Ghaṭikāro kho, mahārāja, kumbhakāro pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
mn81:18.16.eng: And since he has ended the five lower fetters, Ghaṭīkāra will be reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.

mn81:19.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, mahārāja, samayaṃ vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
mn81:19.1.eng: This one time, great king, I was staying near the market town of Vebhaliṅga.

mn81:19.2.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro etadavocaṃ:
mn81:19.2.eng: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,

mn81:19.3.pli: “handa ko nu kho ayaṃ bhaggavo gato”ti?
mn81:19.3.comm: The Buddha uses Ghaṭīkāra’s clan name, as he does at SN 1.50:11.2.

mn81:19.4.pli: “Nikkhanto kho te, bhante, upaṭṭhāko antokumbhiyā odanaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjā”ti.
mn81:19.4.eng: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take rice from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”

mn81:19.5.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, kumbhiyā odanaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mn81:19.5.eng: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.
mn81:19.5.comm: This appears to technically violate Bu Pc 40, which requires that food be given with the hands, not simply by speech. However, not all Buddhas lay down the exact same Vinaya rules. Several parallels explain this by saying that Kassapa was following the customs of the mystical land of Uttarakuru (MA 63 at T i 502a19; T i 502b8; Saṅghabhedavastu 17:391 at Gnoli 1978a:27,14 and D (1) ’dul ba, ga 8a3), where no-one had any possessions (DN 32:7.4).

mn81:19.6.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
mn81:19.6.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,

mn81:19.7.pli: “ko kumbhiyā odanaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
mn81:19.7.eng: “Who took rice from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”

mn81:19.8.pli: “Kassapo, tāta, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kumbhiyā odanaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
mn81:19.8.eng: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”

mn81:19.9.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:

mn81:19.11.pli: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho evaṃ abhivissattho”ti.
mn81:19.11.eng: in that the Buddha Kassapa trusts me so much!”

mn81:19.12.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ pītisukhaṃ na vijahati, sattāhaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ.
mn81:19.12.eng: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.

mn81:20.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, mahārāja, samayaṃ tattheva vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
mn81:20.1.eng: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.

mn81:20.2.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro etadavocaṃ:
mn81:20.2.eng: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,

mn81:20.3.pli: “handa ko nu kho ayaṃ bhaggavo gato”ti?

mn81:20.4.pli: “Nikkhanto kho te, bhante, upaṭṭhāko anto kaḷopiyā kummāsaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjā”ti.
mn81:20.4.eng: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”

mn81:20.5.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, mahārāja, kaḷopiyā kummāsaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
mn81:20.5.eng: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.

mn81:20.6.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
mn81:20.6.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,

mn81:20.7.pli: “ko kaḷopiyā kummāsaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti?
mn81:20.7.eng: “Who took porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”

mn81:20.8.pli: “Kassapo, tāta, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kaḷopiyā kummāsaṃ gahetvā pariyogā sūpaṃ gahetvā paribhuñjitvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkanto”ti.
mn81:20.8.eng: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”

mn81:20.9.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:

mn81:20.11.pli: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho evaṃ abhivissattho”ti.
mn81:20.11.eng: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”

mn81:20.12.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ pītisukhaṃ na vijahati, sattāhaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ.
mn81:20.12.eng: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.

mn81:21.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, mahārāja, samayaṃ tattheva vegaḷiṅge nāma gāmanigame viharāmi.
mn81:21.1.eng: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.

mn81:21.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kuṭi ovassati.
mn81:21.2.eng: Now at that time my hut leaked.

mn81:21.4.pli: “gacchatha, bhikkhave, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa nivesane tiṇaṃ jānāthā”ti.
mn81:21.4.eng: “Mendicants, go to Ghaṭīkāra’s home and find some grass.”

mn81:21.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, mahārāja, te bhikkhū maṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn81:21.5.eng: When I said this, those mendicants said to me,

mn81:21.6.pli: “natthi kho, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa nivesane tiṇaṃ, atthi ca khvāssa āvesane tiṇacchadanan”ti.
mn81:21.6.eng: “Sir, there’s no grass there, but his workshop has a grass roof.”
mn81:21.6.comm: Āvesana is found here and at MN 140:2.1 of a potter’s workshop, at Kd 15:11.5.15 of a sewing hut, and is mentioned at Manu 9.264 as an “artisan’s workshop” (kārukāveśana).

mn81:21.7.pli: “Gacchatha, bhikkhave, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa āvesanaṃ uttiṇaṃ karothā”ti.
mn81:21.7.eng: “Then go to the workshop and strip the grass.”

mn81:21.8.pli: Atha kho te, mahārāja, bhikkhū ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa āvesanaṃ uttiṇamakaṃsu.

mn81:21.9.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa mātāpitaro te bhikkhū etadavocuṃ:
mn81:21.9.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra’s parents said to those mendicants,

mn81:21.10.eng: “Who’s stripping the grass from the workshop?”

mn81:21.11.pli: “Bhikkhū, bhagini, kassapassa bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kuṭi ovassatī”ti.
mn81:21.11.eng: “It’s the mendicants, sister. The Buddha’s hut is leaking.”

mn81:21.12.eng: “Take it, sirs! Take it, dearest ones!”

mn81:21.13.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāro kumbhakāro yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
mn81:21.13.eng: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,

mn81:21.14.eng: “Who stripped the grass from the workshop?”

mn81:21.15.pli: “Bhikkhū, tāta, kassapassa kira bhagavato arahato sammāsambuddhassa kuṭi ovassatī”ti.
mn81:21.15.eng: “It was the mendicants, dear. It seems the Buddha’s hut is leaking.”

mn81:21.16.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa etadahosi:

mn81:21.18.pli: yassa me kassapo bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho evaṃ abhivissattho”ti.
mn81:21.18.eng: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”

mn81:21.19.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ pītisukhaṃ na vijahati, sattāhaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ.
mn81:21.19.eng: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.

mn81:21.20.pli: Atha kho, mahārāja, āvesanaṃ sabbantaṃ temāsaṃ ākāsacchadanaṃ aṭṭhāsi, na devotivassi.
mn81:21.20.eng: Then the workshop remained with the atmosphere for a roof for the whole three months, but the heavens did not rain on it.

mn81:21.21.eng: And that, great king, is what Ghaṭīkāra the potter is like.’

mn81:21.22.pli: ‘Lābhā, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa, suladdhā, bhante, ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa
mn81:21.22.eng: ‘Ghaṭīkāra the potter is fortunate, very fortunate,

mn81:21.23.eng: to be so trusted by the Buddha Kassapa.’

mn81:22.1.pli: Atha kho, ānanda, kikī kāsirājā ghaṭikārassa kumbhakārassa pañcamattāni taṇḍulavāhasatāni pāhesi paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṃ.
mn81:22.1.eng: Then King Kikī sent around five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce to Ghaṭīkāra.
mn81:22.1.comm: “Suitable sauce” (tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṁ) is also at DN 17:2.15.10 and SN 22.96:4.10, where it describes a similarly luxurious meal. | A secondary theme of this parable is to highlight the different attitudes to offering. Kikī is generous, but his offering is extravagant and indulgent, and ultimately serves his desires, whereas Ghaṭīkāra is concerned only to help with what is needed at the time.

mn81:22.2.pli: Atha kho te, ānanda, rājapurisā ghaṭikāraṃ kumbhakāraṃ upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
mn81:22.2.eng: Then one of the king’s men approached Ghaṭīkāra and said,

mn81:22.3.pli: ‘imāni kho, bhante, pañcamattāni taṇḍulavāhasatāni kikinā kāsirājena pahitāni paṇḍupuṭakassa sālino tadupiyañca sūpeyyaṃ.
mn81:22.3.eng: ‘Sir, these five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce have been sent to you by King Kikī of Kāsi.

mn81:22.5.eng: ‘The king has many duties, and much to do.

mn81:22.6.comm: The two words alaṁ me encapsulate the radical basis of a Buddhist economy.

mn81:22.7.eng: Let this be for the king himself.’

mn81:23.1.pli: Siyā kho pana te, ānanda, evamassa:

mn81:23.2.pli: ‘añño nūna tena samayena jotipālo māṇavo ahosī’ti.
mn81:23.2.eng: ‘Surely the student Jotipāla must have been someone else at that time?’
mn81:23.2.comm: This phrase marks canonical Jātaka stories at DN 17:2.14.2, MN 83:21.2, AN 3.15:5.2, and AN 9.20:5.2.

mn81:23.3.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, ānanda, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ.
mn81:23.3.eng: But you should not see it like this.

mn81:23.4.pli: Ahaṃ tena samayena jotipālo māṇavo ahosin”ti.
mn81:23.4.eng: I myself was the student Jotipāla at that time.”

mn81:23.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

mn81:23.6.pli: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
mn81:23.6.eng: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
